questions.text: A 62-year-old patient is diagnosed with a large, invasive adenocarcinoma of the splenic flexure of the colon. The colorectal surgeon recommends surgical resection. Which of the following colectomy procedures would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Colectomy

Structures removed

Total Colectomy

Removal of entire colon

Total Proctocolectomy

Total Colectomy + removal of rectum

Subtotal Colectomy

Removal of entire colon except the rectum

Right Hemicolectomy

Terminal ileum, cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, right half of transverse colon

Extended Right Hemicolectomy

Terminal ileum, cecum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, proximal 2/3rd of transverse colon

Left Hemicolectomy

Distal 1/3rd of transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, portion of sigmoid colon

Extended Left Hemicolectomy

Distal 2/3rd of transverse colon, splenic flexure, descending colon, portion of sigmoid colon

Transverse Colectomy

Removal of the transverse colon

Sigmoid Colectomy

Removal of the sigmoid colon

questions.text: A 15-year-old patient is diagnosed with juvenile polyposis syndrome (JPS). Which of the following statements accurately describes the management and characteristics of JPS?

options.label: A
options.text: The initial colonoscopy screening should be started by age 10

options.label: B
options.text: JPS is caused by mutations in the SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes

options.label: C
options.text: Prophylactic colectomy is indicated only when iron-deficiency anemia is present

options.label: D
options.text: Best managed with immediate total colectomy regardless of the number of polyps

questions.correct_answer: B. JPS is caused by mutations in the SMAD4 or BMPR1A genes
questions.explanation:
Juvenile polyp

Genetics

Autosomal dominant inheritance; Mutations in BMPR1A, SMAD4, or ENG genes

Key Characteristics
  • Hamartomatous polyps in intestines
  • No pigmentation (unlike Peutz–Jeghers syndrome)

Cancer Risk

10% to 38% lifetime risk of colon cancer; Average age of diagnosis: 34 years

Clinical Diagnosis
  • At least five juvenile polyps in the colorectum
  • Multiple juvenile polyps throughout the GI tract
  • Any number of juvenile polyps with a family history of JPS

Symptoms
  • Acute or chronic gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Prolapsed rectal polyps
  • Abdominal pain
  • Diarrhea

Screening Recommendations
  • Initial colonoscopy between ages 12 and 15 (Option A)
  • Repeat colonoscopy in 2-3 years if no polyps are found
  • Annual colonoscopies if polyps are found and removed

Surgical Indications (Option D)
  • High-grade dysplasia or cancer presence
  • Polyp burden unmanageable endoscopically

Surgical Options
  • Subtotal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis (IRA)
  • Segmental colectomy
  • Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Prophylactic Surgery Considerations (Option C)
  • Poor surveillance compliance
  • Family history of colorectal cancer

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with acute lower gastrointestinal bleeding. He is hemodynamically stable but has a significant amount of blood in his stool. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Lower GI Bleeding

Definition

Bleeding from the GI tract distal to the ligament of Treitz (jejunum to anus).

Causes
  • Diverticular Disease: Pouches in the colon wall.
  • Angiodysplasia: Vascular malformation with dilated, tortuous submucosal veins in the colon.
  • Heyde’s disease: Characterized by both aortic stenosis and angiodysplasia.
  • IBD: Inflammation and ulceration.
  • Colonic Polyps: Growths in the colon.
  • Colorectal Cancer: Bleeding, bowel habit changes, anaemia.
  • Infectious Colitis: Bloody diarrhoea, possible perforation.
  • Ischemic Colitis: Reduced blood flow, bleeding in splenic flexure.

Management
  • Active Bleeding with Hypovolemic Shock: CT angiogram, embolisation, inpatient colonoscopy, therapeutic endoscopy/surgery.
  • Significant Bleeding without Hypovolemic Shock: Inpatient colonoscopy, EGD, capsule endoscopy/CT angiogram/nuclear medicine scanning.
  • Minor Bleeding: Outpatient investigations.
  • General Considerations: Withhold anticoagulants, transfuse blood products as needed.

Treatment Specifics
  • Angiodysplasia: CT angiography, embolisation, colonoscopy, argon laser, surgery if severe.
  • Diverticular Disease: High-fiber diet, laxatives, antibiotics, surgery for complications.

Importance of Accurate Diagnosis

Differentiating between diverticular bleeding and angiodysplasia is crucial for appropriate treatment. Early diagnosis improves outcomes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and low-grade fever. Her medical history includes hypertension and a recent episode of congestive heart failure. An abdominal CT scan reveals signs of bowel ischemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ischemic Colitis

Definition

Ischemic colitis is the most common form of gastrointestinal ischemia. It occurs when there is insufficient blood flow to the colon, leading to tissue injury.

Causes
  • Thrombotic occlusion: Often linked to atherosclerosis; presents with abdominal pain, raised white cell count, and rectal bleeding.
  • Embolic events: Can cause acute ischemia with severe pain, bloody diarrhea, and hemodynamic instability.
  • Low-flow states: Conditions like septic shock, heart failure, and hypotension increase the risk.

Risk Factors
  • Predominantly affects older adults, women, and individuals with comorbidities.
  • Increased risk in case of atherosclerosis, abdominal surgeries, certain medications, and illicit drug use.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Sudden abdominal pain, tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, low-grade fever, abdominal distension, and tenderness.
  • Mild cases may have nonspecific symptoms; severe cases can lead to shock and require urgent treatment.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging:
    • Abdominal plain films may show "thumb-printing";
    • CT scans with contrast are preferred.
  • Colonoscopy: Gold standard for diagnosis, showing characteristic mucosal changes.
  • Vascular Imaging: Used in suspected acute mesenteric ischemia.

Treatment
  • Conservative Management: Includes bowel rest, IV fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and addressing underlying conditions.
  • Surgical Intervention: Necessary for severe cases; involves removing gangrenous bowel and ensuring adequate blood supply.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a 5-day history of watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fever. He was recently treated with cephalosporins for a respiratory infection. Upon examination, the patient is dehydrated but stable. Endoscopy reveals raised yellowish-white plaques on the colonic mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pseudomembranous Colitis

Cause
  • Primarily caused by Clostridium difficile infection.
  • Often associated with antibiotic use, especially cephalosporins.

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, fever.
  • Severe cases: Pseudomembranous colitis with raised, yellowish-white plaques on colonic mucosa.
  • Nonspecific colitis or fulminant colitis may also occur, with a higher risk of perforation.

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical symptoms and stool tests for C. difficile toxins, antigens, or bacteria.
  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy for inconclusive stool tests or excluding other causes.
  • Colonoscopy used cautiously in fulminant colitis.

Treatment
  • Antibiotics: Oral vancomycin, fidaxomicin, or metronidazole.
  • Fecal microbiota transplantation for unresponsive cases.
  • Emergency subtotal colectomy and ileostomy for severe cases.

Prevention
  • Isolation of suspected cases.
  • Use of protective equipment by healthcare staff.
  • Thorough disinfection and meticulous hand hygiene.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, recently diagnosed with colon and bladder cancer, presents with a notable family history; her mother also had both cancers and succumbed to them. Additionally, she has a history of sebaceous adenomas. Which other malignancy should she be evaluated for, considering the potential hereditary cancer syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • A genetic disorder characterised by sebaceous tumours and internal malignancies.
  • Variant of Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer).

Genetic Basis
  • Mutations in mismatch repair genes: MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EPCAM.
  • Inheritance: Autosomal dominant.

Associated Cancers

Sebaceous Tumors

Includes adenomas, carcinomas, and hyperplasia.

Colorectal Cancer

Most common. Diagnosed by colonoscopy and genetic testing.

Genitourinary Cancers

Includes bladder, ureters, and kidneys. Diagnosed with imaging and cystoscopy.

Breast Cancer

Managed with mammography and possibly breast MRI.

Other Cancers

Includes non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

Diagnostic Modalities
  • Genetic Testing: To identify MMR gene mutations.
  • Microsatellite Instability Testing
  • Immunohistochemistry: MMR protein expression.

Management and Counseling
  • Surveillance
  • Preventive measures like prophylactic surgery and lifestyle modifications.
  • Genetic counseling and family testing

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the therapy for colon carcinoma are correct? Statements: Chemotherapy is often used in the adjuvant setting after surgery to reduce the risk of recurrence in patients with Stage III colon cancer. Immunotherapy is typically used as a first-line treatment for patients with colon cancer who have microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficiency. Chemotherapy with FOLFOX (5-Fluorouracil, Leucovorin, and Oxaliplatin) is commonly used for Stage IV colon cancer to achieve a cure. Checkpoint inhibitors like Pembrolizumab are effective in colon cancer patients with microsatellite instability-high (MSI-H) or mismatch repair deficiency. Radiotherapy is not preferred for colon cancer due to its limited benefit in local control.
questions.explanation:
Regimen

Components

FOLFOX
  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
  • Folinic Acid
  • Oxaliplatin

FOLFIRI
  • 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU)
  • Folinic Acid
  • Irinotecan

CapeOx
  • Capecitabine
  • Oxaliplatin

Category

Drug

Mechanism of Action

Immunotherapy

Pembrolizumab

(Checkpoint inhibitor) PD-1 inhibitor

Nivolumab

PD-1 inhibitor (sometimes combined with Ipilimumab)

Ipilimumab

CTLA-4 inhibitor (sometimes combined with Nivolumab)

Targeted Therapy

Bevacizumab

Anti-VEGF antibody, inhibits blood vessel formation

Cetuximab

Anti-EGFR antibody, effective in KRAS wild-type tumours

Panitumumab

Similar to Cetuximab, fully humanized to reduce allergic reactions

questions.text: A 62-year-old male underwent a right hemicolectomy for carcinoma of the colon. On the fourth postoperative day, he developed severe abdominal pain, fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. On physical examination, his abdomen is distended and diffusely tender with guarding and rigidity. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals free fluid and air in the peritoneal cavity. Considering the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely cause of his current condition?
questions.explanation:
Surgical Procedure

Level of Injury

Nerve Injured

Clinical Features

High Inferior Mesenteric Artery (IMA) Ligation

Near sacral promontory

Superior Hypogastric Plexus

Retrograde ejaculation in men due to sympathetic dysfunction

Division of Lateral Stalks Close to Pelvic Sidewall

Lateral stalks near pelvic sidewall

Pelvic Plexus & Nervi Erigentes

Erectile dysfunction, impotence, and atonic bladder

Anterior Dissection

Periprostatic region

Periprostatic Plexus

Sexual dysfunction and bladder dysfunction (e.g., incontinence)

Low Anterior Resection

Pelvic splanchnic nerves

Pelvic Splanchnic Nerves

Urinary incontinence and bowel dysfunction

Total Mesorectal Excision (TME)

Within the mesorectum

Autonomic nerves within the mesorectum

Erectile dysfunction in men, urinary incontinence

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, and intermittent abdominal pain. He has a history of occasional rectal bleeding. On examination, he has mild pallor, and there is a palpable mass in the right upper quadrant. A colonoscopy is performed, revealing a large ulcerative mass at the hepatic flexure of the colon. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of adenocarcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Segmental resection of the hepatic flexure

questions.explanation:
Site of Colon Cancer

Surgery Performed

Diagram of Surgery

Cecum & ascending colon

Right hemicolectomy

 ascending colon.png" data-author="NA" data-hash="7836" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/4ph9HfSExQME2c1Q54jy1744005827.png" />

Hepatic flexure

Extended right hemicolectomy

 Hepatic flexure" data-author="NA" data-hash="7837" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RcDnnqCtHqgOupVIrsZj1744005866.png" />

Transverse colon

Transverse colectomy

 Transverse colon" data-author="NA" data-hash="7838" data-license="NA" data-source="NA" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/HqpZnJL3C8XYFtBdrn431744005912.png" />

Splenic flexure

Extended left hemicolectomy

Descending colon

Left hemicolectomy

Sigmoid colon

Sigmoid colectomy

Rectosigmoid junction, upper rectum

& middle rectum

Low Anterior Resection (LAR)

Lower rectum

Abdominoperineal Resection (APR)

questions.text: A 54-year-old female with intractable diarrhea and pigmentation was diagnosed with Cronkhite-Canada syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding the disease are true? Hamartomatous polyp of colon Seen only in females Polyps can be present in the stomach and duodenum as well 15% can turn malignant
Which chemotherapy regimen is standard for adjuvant treatment in a patient with stage III colon cancer?
questions.explanation:
STAGE OF COLON CANCER

CHEMOTHERAPY

STAGE III

FOLFOX

  • FOL: Folinic acid (Leucovorin)
  • F: 5-Fluorouracil
  • OX: Oxaliplatin

STAGE IV/Metastatic Colon Cancer

First-line therapy: FOLFIRI

  • FOL: Folinic acid (Leucovorin)
  • F: 5-Fluorouracil
  • IRI: Irinotecan
 

Second line therapy:

  • Bevacizumab - VEGF inhibitor
  • Cetuximab - EGFR inhibitor

questions.text: A 72-year-old female is found to have a 3 cm mass in the ascending colon during colonoscopy. A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows no evidence of lymph node involvement or distant metastases. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform a right hemicolectomy with en-bloc lymph node dissection.

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend adjuvant chemotherapy following the surgical resection.

options.label: C
options.text: Proceed with endoscopic mucosal resection of the tumor.

questions.correct_answer: A. Perform a right hemicolectomy with en-bloc lymph node dissection.
questions.explanation:
STAGING

TREATMENT

Stage 0 (Tis, N0, M0)

Endoscopic polypectomy

Stage 1 (T1, N0, M0)

Segmental colectomy

Stage 2 (T1-3,N0,M0)

Surgical resection with 5 cm margin and anastomosis

Stage 3 (T any, N1, M0)

Surgical resection + adjuvant chemotherapy

Stage 4 (T any, N any, M1)

Resection of metastases + palliative chemotherapy/radiotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following is a possible description of a T3 colon tumour?

options.label: C
options.text: Tumour invades adjacent organs or structures

questions.explanation:
T (Tumor)

Tis

Carcinoma in situ/tumour confined to mucosa (Option D)

T1

Tumour invades the submucosa (Option A)

T2

Tumour invades the muscularis propria

T3

Tumour invades through subserosa or into pericolorectal tissues

T4a

Tumours breach the visceral peritoneum

T4b

Tumor directly invades or is adherent to other organs or structures (Option C)

N (Lymph Node)

N1a

Metastasis in 1 regional lymph node.

N1b

Metastasis in 2-3 regional lymph nodes.

N1c

Tumor deposits in the subserosa, mesentery, or non-peritonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues without regional nodal metastasis.

N2a

Metastasis in 4-6 regional lymph nodes.

N2b

Metastasis in 7 or more regional lymph nodes.

M (Metastasis)

M1a

Metastasis confined to one organ or site

M1b

Metastasis to more than one organ/site or the peritoneum.

M1c

Metastasis to the peritoneum with or without other organ involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Modified Dukes' Staging System for colorectal cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Dukes A: Tumour invades the muscularis propria but no lymph node involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Dukes B: Tumour penetrates through the muscularis propria with positive lymph nodes

options.label: C
options.text: Dukes C: Tumour invades beyond the bowel wall, no lymph node involvement

options.label: D
options.text: Dukes D: Tumour has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status

questions.correct_answer: D. Dukes D: Tumour has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status
questions.explanation:
STAGING

DESCRIPTION

Dukes A

(Option A)

Tumor confined to the mucosa (Stage I in modern TNM staging).

Dukes B

(Option B)
  • B1- Partial penetration of muscularis propria
  • B2- Full penetration of muscularis propria

Dukes C

(Option C)
  • C1- LN involvement without penetration of entire bowel wall
  • C2- LN involvement with penetration of entire bowel wall

Dukes D

(Option D)

Tumor has distant metastasis regardless of lymph node status

questions.text: On barium enema investigation of a 54-year-old male with colon cancer an apple core lesion was found. What is the location of the carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Right-Sided Tumours

Left-Sided Tumours

Location

Cecum, ascending colon, proximal transverse colon

Distal transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon

Growth pattern

Typically polypoid or fungating

Often annular or constricting

Common symptoms
  • Anemia (due to chronic blood loss)
  • Fatigue
  • Weakness
  • Abdominal mass
  • Altered bowel habits
  • Constipation
  • Narrow stools
  • Obstruction

Pain

Less common, vague discomfort

More common, colicky pain

Bleeding

Occult bleeding (melena)

Hematochezia (bright red blood)

Physical exam

Palpable mass in right iliac fossa

Less likely to have a palpable mass

Barium enema finding

Filling defect

"Apple core" lesion

Iron deficiency anaemia

More common

Less common

questions.text: Arrange the steps in the pathogenesis of colon cancer Dysplasia Intermediate adenoma DNA methylation 18q loss DCC

A 62-year-old male with a history of long-standing ulcerative colitis presents with rectal bleeding, unintentional weight loss, and altered bowel habits. A colonoscopy reveals a large, ulcerated mass in the sigmoid colon, and a biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. Which of these factors in his history would not have served as risk factors for developing colon cancer?
questions.explanation:
Dietary Risk Factors
  • High red meat (Option D)
  • Low dietary fiber intake
  • High-fat diet
  • Alcohol consumption
  • Cigarette smoking (Option B)
  • Lack of dietary vitamins A, C, E, and zinc

Genetic Risk Factors
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)
  • Gardner's syndrome
  • Turcot's syndrome
  • Family history of colon cancer (2-4 times increased risk)
  • Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC)

Medical Risk Factors
  • Long-standing ulcerative colitis (Option A)
  • Crohn's disease (less risk compared to ulcerative colitis)
  • History of cholecystectomy
  • Ileal resection (increased bile salts)
  • Radiation exposure (mucinous type)
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy (100-500 times increased risk)
  • Acromegaly

PROTECTIVE FACTORS
  • High-fiber diet
  • Dietary calcium
  • Aspirin and other NSAIDs (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate screening method for colon cancer?
questions.explanation:
Screening Method

Description

Advantages

Limitations

Fecal Occult Blood Test (FOBT) (Option C)
  • Nonspecific
  • Detects peroxidase activity in hemoglobin

Simple and non-invasive

Low specificity

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy (Option A)

Once every 5 years to identify adenomas, often combined with FOBT

Direct visualisation

Limited to the lower colon

Colonoscopy (Option B)

Most accurate

Comprehensive and therapeutic
  • Bowel preparation
  • Invasive

Air Contrast Barium Enema

Detects polyps larger than 1 cm
  • Non-invasive
  • Can evaluate the entire colon

Less accurate in the sigmoid colon

CT Colonography (Virtual Colonoscopy) (Option D)

Helical CT scan that creates 3D images of the colon's interior
  • Non-invasive
  • Detailed imaging
  • Requires bowel preparation
  • Air insufflation
  • Radiation
